title: Tuesday, 19th July, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM

PM

PM

PM

And we have readers

PM

Bizarrely

PM

PM

PM

11:04 am
PM

BE

Hi.

PM

Nice break?

11:05 am
BE

Yeah, better than being here certainly. Though a tad irritated to have missed the Arm takeover story, having waited 15 years for it.

ARM Holdings PLC (ARM:LSE): Last: 1,670, down 4.98 (-0.30%), High: 1,675, Low: 1,668, Volume: 12.47m
PM

I know i know

11:05 am

PM

Cos Ive been lazy these X past years

PM

I never had to know anything about ARM

11:06 am
PM

Cos it was you're starter for 10

BE

I'm a bit behind on the press coverage, but what I've read has been .......... sometimes a little odd.

PM

Odd?

11:07 am
BE

We're worried about Arm being taken over by them foreigners, right? Jewel in the crown of the UK tech industry, yes?

PM

oh that

BE

That line of thinking seems, to me, not entirely logical. In terms of ownership, Arm was already mostly foreign. It was just a lot of foreign investment managers.

11:08 am
PM

(capital -- he's saying "hold a few" -- will share in a mo when Bryce has got out what he wants to say on this)

BE

And is Softbank going to asset strip and move it out of Cambridge? Well, why would it?

BE

It's paid 47 times 2016

11:08 am
BE

With zero -- ZERO! -- synergies.

PM

Is Internet of Things, innit?

BE

On which I'm not as negative as the press coverage either.

11:10 am
BE

There's a lot of "internet fridge" in the press this morning, and a lot of hackable webcam type stuff, which are the default lines of cynicism about IoT.

BE

All it tells you is that hardware gets developed before software.

BE

If Softbank throws money are the right people in the right places, as Son has promised, there's no reason why there can't be an ARM11 in every bus stop and fire alarm by 2025.

11:11 am
BE

Does that justify the price? Probably not.

BE

And note, Softbank took just 14 days to do this deal. FOURTEEN DAYS.

BE

From approach to finalisation. That's .................. quite something.

11:12 am
PM

hmm

PM

It is

BE

There's every chance that Softbank's making a mistake here, but it's not likely to impact Arm that much.

11:13 am
BE

Because Arm's infrastructural to the industry. Indispensable, even.

BE

It'll get a lot more investment than shareholders (as in, the UK ones) would've stomached, then perhaps be spun off five or ten years from now with Qualcomm and Apple etc taking non-competing stakes.

BE

That's a summary of what I'd have said yesterday, when it was relevant.

11:14 am
PM

ok

PM

thank you

PM

I was just reading this stuff from Vitaliy Katsenelson taht Dan pinged over

11:15 am
PM

What would you get if you crossed Warren Buffett, Richard Branson and Steve Jobs? Answer: Masayoshi Son, the Korean-Japanese, University of California, Berkeley–educated founder of one of Japan’s most successful companies, SoftBank Corp.

PM

Just like Buffett, Son is a tremendous capital allocator with a very impressive record: Over the past nine and a half years, SoftBank’s investments have had a 45 percent annualized rate of return. A big chunk of this success can be attributed to one stock: Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba, a $100 million investment SoftBank made in 2001 that is worth about $80 billion today. Though you may put Alibaba in the (positive) black swan column, Son’s success as an investor goes well beyond it — the list of his investments that have brought multibagger returns is very long. Today, at the tender age of 57, he is the richest man in Japan, and SoftBank, which he started in 1981 and owns 19 percent of, has a market capitalization of $72 billion.

PM

Etc

11:16 am
PM

http://contrariane...obs-at-a-discount/

PM

But this caught my eye

PM

What is shocking is that Son saw that the iPhone would revolutionize the telecom industry before Apple announced it or even invented it. See for yourself in this excerpt from an interview with Charlie Rose, where Son describes his conversation with Jobs in 2005 — two years before the iPhone was introduced:

11:16 am
PM

“I brought my little drawing of [an] iPod with mobile capabilities. I gave [Jobs] my drawing, and Steve says, “Masa, you don’t give me your drawing. I have my own.” I said, “Well, I don’t need to give you my dirty paper, but once you have your product, give me for Japan.” He said, “Well, Masa, you are crazy. We have not talked to anybody, but you came to see me as the first guy. I give to you.”

PM

How is that clairvoyant -- to suggest that the ipod might have mobile capabilities??

BE

(@Mouselet: yes, true, fair. I more meant what Son was talking about yesterday that cars, for instance, will become the equivalent of supercomputers.)

11:17 am
PM

The iphone existed in non-iphone form well before Apple started making them

PM

You missed Neil Camplilng's excitement yesterday

PM

He was out of bed before 3am

11:17 am
BE

Of course. This is Neil's Glastonbury ........

PM

He's caught up on his sleep since

PM

But still hugely bullish

11:18 am
PM

Softbank themselves did a poor job explaining the rationale on the conference call in our view and it seems to have been an opportunistic strike. ARM is an awesome asset we think and, if they execute and keep the culture as promised then, in 10 years time it may look to be a masterstroke. But short term is a different matter. The other thing is - there is no break-up fee, no lock in. ARM has opened the doors to a counter in our view. And the more we think about it the more likely and sensible it is for others to run the rule over this. Remember, the start of this deal was born just two weeks ago. So quick that the usual bankers and the Frank Quattrone Mafia etc to not even have time to pitch in Cali. There are a range of potential suitors.

PM

Let's take just one example. Apple reluctantly depends on Samsung for a range of technologies - for flash memory, displays (and soon to be even more dependent as Samsung looks to dominate OLED - although it makes OLED US, AMAT US, and 034220 KS buys as this will be the biggest technology push over the next 12 months), and sometimes (less so lately due to TSMC share gains) for foundry. Apple is often actually behind Samsung on the technology curve and has been playing catch up over multiple years. So why doesn't Apple turn the tables and make Samsung dependent on Apple for their ARM cores in their technology products: phones, tablets, next gen cloud computing, autonomous vehicle technology etc. And we suspect Apple would rather ditch OS X and move to one iOS based platform in time (see previous notes on this). Apple is now sitting on $233B of cash, of which we know $208.9B, or 90%, is sitting overseas (Source Apple conference call 26/4/16). Putting $30-$40B of that to work on acquiring the DNA of the Internet of Everything (aka ARM) would certainly be a more strategic purchase than, say, the $24.4B Microsoft are spending on LinkedIn, for example, in our view.

PM

Other suitors, in our mind, include: TSMC; Intel; Qualcomm; Microsoft and Google. While we couldn't criticise anyone wanting to lock in some profits, we would be inclined to keep some as this could be just the start of the movie rather than the end.

11:19 am
BE

Intel would be very difficult as it'd require tearing up a four-decade roadmap. TSMC, maybe. Google would be a big issue given the Android-IOS tensions.

BE

Microsoft ...... I'm sure the folk in Cambridge would much rather be owned by a profligate Japanese company with a crazy balance sheet than .... well, Microsoft.

PM

indeed

11:21 am
BE

Qualcomm is the one we've discussed for about a decade. It's implausible to imagine that Qualcomm hasn't looked at buying Arm, and could've done it at a quarter of the current price if it had picked its moment.

BE

I see no particular threat to Qualcomm's model from Softbank owning Arm, so ... nah. Doubt it.

ARM Holdings PLC (ARM:LSE): Last: 1,669, down 6 (-0.36%), High: 1,675, Low: 1,668, Volume: 13.89m
11:22 am
BE

Want some sector implications from Morgan Stanley?

PM

sure

BE

We believe that the acquisition of Arm by Softbank could have a more
profound effect on the semiconductor industry than may at first
appear.
We acknowledge that investors have been worried recently about ARM, we
think because of the slowdown in smartphones and the increased R&D
investment with no obvious return in the short term, despite the potential to
gain more market share in cloud, servers, networks and IoT.

11:22 am
BE

This has perhaps provided a good opportunity for Softbank to buy a high
quality asset as the JPY strengthened vs the GBP post the EU referendum. The
conference call indicated that Softbank had admired the ARM business
model for a long time and saw more value long term than the market
was seeing short term. (The deal is contingent on approval by ARM
shareholders.)

BE

Softbank wants ARM to invest more in R&D and, assuming the strategy
bears fruit, this is unlikely to leave Intel immune in servers - especially
with Softbank close to Alibaba in terms of shareholding structure - and Alibaba
has indicated in the past interest in ARM's based servers. This could also
accelerate the development of chips for networks, with Softbank already
involved in planning for 5G.

BE

Should the Softbank acquisition of ARM not be as successful as
planned, this could enhance Intel's chances of retaining its lead in
servers or allow Imagination to finally thrive in the semiconductor IP
market, in our view.
China has been a big purchaser of ARM IP in the past 2-3 years, with revenues
from China in some quarters amounting to half of licensing revenues. Would
Softbank exploit that new geopolitical trend? That is one of the many
unanswered question in this deal, which is highly unlikely to be neutral for the
tech industry overall.

11:23 am
BE

From the standpoint of the data center market, the ARM server opportunity has been slow to materialize. But the
most likely outcome of Softbank moving to a higher investment profile could be a renewed commitment to the
ARM server ecosystem. We do see early stage investment in ARM servers from Chinese vendors, notably
Alibaba, which has ties to Softbank. We expect Intel to remain the dominant force in server microprocessors for
the foreseeable future, but would see the evolution of an ARM server ecosystem to be an important limiter to
Intel's ability to continue to raise selling prices in this segment. In the US, we see Cavium as a significant
beneficiary of the ARM server opportunity; while it has been slow to evolve, we see important progress.

BE

(@Otter: it looks a bit tricky to me, but then I have similar thoughts about Liberty.)

BE

(@Otter: actually, speaking of ...... Softbank sum of the parts from Deutsche Bank.

11:24 am
BE

BE

There's about $9bn lost in the conglomerate discount.

BE

Though they've valued Arm at the pre-takeout price, which might be a tad harsh if you believe in the long-term vision.

11:25 am
BE

One final point on all this, also from Deutsche.

BE

I believe the "Japanese company buys something ... therefore JT will probably buy Imperial" thing was going round again yesterday.

BE

Because any excuse to revive that rumour.

11:27 am
BE

Deutsche go through why it doesn't really make sense on the Yen-sterling theory.

BE

Linking Imperial Brands (IMB) to Softbank/Arm is a stretch, but for some it’s there. While we struggle with the link, we think it worth going through the arguments, also noting the potential implications for British American Tobacco (BAT.LN, Buy 4835.00p). IMB potentially being acquired by Japan Tobacco (JT, JPY4270.00) has been the subject of numerous press articles (e.g. Financial Times 6 July 2016, The Guardian 8 Dec. 2015). For some, there is logic in the link between Arm/Softbank and Imperial/JT, in light of the long standing press coverage and GBP/Yen having fallen c30% in the last year, thereby reducing the Yen cost of a potential deal. While that may be so, we consider it too simplistic to look at a potential deal in Yen cost terms.

BE

1) GBP/Yen may make a potential deal smaller in Yen terms but the Yen EBITDA acquired by JT falls by a similar amount so the multiple/value equation doesn't materially change, just the size.
2) If lower costs in Yen terms were to be the reason for a potential deal, we note our house view is the GBP goes lower.
3) Financing logic would suggest that if there were a deal, JT should match funding currencies with Imperial’s EBITDA thus diluting some of the 'FX value'.
4) Irrespective of FX, the Japanese government is a c33% shareholder in JT and may be a hindrance to a potential deal. The company has said that the government has until 2022 to sell down its JT stake.

11:27 am
BE

5) Don't ignore BAT, where the press has widely reported potential interest in Imperial (e.g. Bloomberg 20 November 2015). Assume JT takes IMB out at a 30% premium (in line with the typical premium in staples). That would be a 2016E EBITDA multiple of 17x vs. current 14x. We believe JT may have to sell c c20% of IMB (or more) for regulatory reasons if any deal materialises with BAT a potential buyer (for regulatory reasons we believe PMI would be an unlikely buyer). BAT would not pay the same multiple to JT as JT pays for IMB in our view as a lot of what they would buy would be in the UK with lower growth than the IMB average. Assume BAT pays JT a multiple 25% below that paid by JT to compensate for the lower growth, i.e. c14.3x FY16E. Any potential deal would take c12 months to close so we base everything on 2019E. Assume a) BAT buys 2019E EBITDA of GPB875m (20% of 2019E per DBe) b) BAT adds synergies of £75m (DBe) as duplicate costs are taken out c) there is a 3% funding cost. On this basis a potential deal would be c7% EPS accretive to BAT in 2019E and take BAT net debt/EBITDA to 3.1x from 1.9x.

Imperial Brands PLC (IMB:LSE): Last: 4,000, down 9.5 (-0.24%), High: 4,021, Low: 3,982, Volume: 349.60k
BE

And there endeth yesterday's news.

11:31 am
Gulf Keystone Petroleum Ltd (GKP:LSE): Last: 7.31, up 1.71 (+30.50%), High: 8.00, Low: 5.50, Volume: 68.73m
BE

I've read the "shorts closing" idea .... Why would you close a short (unless it was getting called) if you have that much new supply about to appear? Is there something in the mechanics there that I'm missing?

BE

We see this quite a bit, I guess. I remember Yell rallying 50% a day for about a week, before being suspended.

11:32 am
BE

Then along came the Shareholder Action Groups, griping that they'd been lied to somehow.

PM

hehehe

BE

(@Bluesky21: one would assume those who are short are either serious folk who won't fall out with their prime broker over a fairly small position, or spread betters hedging their clients.)

11:33 am
PM

Actually I have a buy note for GKP

BE

!

PM

From Exotix

11:33 am
BE

Oh.

PM

But it's for the bonds, not the stock

BE

Ah.

11:34 am
PM

Recovery for guaranteed bondholders: in our central case we value this as the sum of the equity valuation with a conservative production plan and consensus prices for oil (83 cents) and the new bond assuming a PIK option at an exit yield of 14% (28 cents) for a total recovery value of 111 cents. As an equity play post restructuring, there could be further upside as an unleveraged company will have the opportunity to invest to grow production as long as the positive payment cycle from the MNR continues.
Recovery for convertible bondholders: this ranges from 14 to 30 cents. Our central case estimate is 20 cents (using a conservative production plan and consensus prices for oil).
The restructuring is to be conducted via a UK scheme of arrangement with the company and bondholders. The transaction requires the approval of existing shareholders and consent of no less than 75% by value and a majority in number of both guaranteed and convertible bondholders who participate and vote at each creditor meeting. There is support from 66% of the guaranteed bonds and 50% of the convertible Bonds, as well as some large shareholders.

PM

The company is subject to multiple risks: concentration of production in one field, exposure to oil prices, lack of tools to prevent non-payment of crude sales, exposure to geopolitical and terrorism issues as well as the usual risks linked to an upcoming debt restructuring.
The guaranteed bonds’ indicative price jumped more than 15 points while the convertibles were relatively stable, following the publication of the restructuring proposal yesterday. We continue to see upside in restructuring for the guaranteed bonds and believe that there could potentially be more upside in the post-restructuring equity play. We reiterate our Buy recommendation on the 13% 2017 guaranteed bonds. We also see an attractive risk-reward scenario for the convertible bonds and are introducing a Buy recommendation for them, although our preferred option remains the guaranteed bonds.

PM

They have a long,detailed note from back in May on all this

11:35 am
PM

I will usual place it

undefined
BE

Back up to the leaderboard, I guess.

11:35 am
BE

Slew of headlines on Sky

Sky PLC (SKY:LSE): Last: 894.00, up 14 (+1.59%), High: 902.00, Low: 882.50, Volume: 2.15m
BE

Firstly with regards to the government still (in theory) pushing BT to fix stuff.

11:36 am
BE

Which I guess we'll get to in a moment. First, though, RBC's turned positive on Sky.

BE

Our view: We upgrade Sky to Outperform with a 1,100p PT (was 1,000p).
Our view reflects (1) the lower share price; (2) de-risking of rights renewal
in Germany; (3) upside from mobile rollout. The rise in PT is partly driven
by our forecasts for higher outer year earnings in GBP terms from Germany
and Italy.

BE

No mention in here whatsoever of the 21C Fox buyout, which has been the subject of plenty of speculative pieces over the past few weeks.

11:38 am
BE

Instead, it's all about Sky's entry into one of the world's most competitive mobile markets

BE

Mobile strategy: Sky has been competing as a triple play operator
following its acquisition of Easynet back in 2004. This has enabled Sky to
compete on the price of its bundle by offering cheap fixed line services. Sky
is finally set to launch a 'thick MVNO' this year, moving Sky from triple play
to quad play. Although Sky could arguably afford to buy O2 following the
failure of the Hutch/O2 deal (our full merger model suggests accretion),
we do not believe it will do so. In our view, its optimal strategy is to roll out
the MVNO, gaining scale quickly through bundled offers to the c.40% of
UK homes that take Sky. Later on Sky could look to buy spectrum directly
to reduce marginal cost.

PM

thick MVNO?

11:39 am
BE

"Not Lebara or Tesco Mobile", I think that means.

PM

Because MVNOs are effectively defined by their lack of spectrum licenses, an MVNO necessarily will need to have agreements in place to access the network of at least one MNO. The type of MVNO is determined by how "thick" or "thin" of a technological layer an MVNO adds over its access to its host MNO's network.

PM

(From the wiki on it)

11:40 am
BE

Well, thanks.

BE

Maximising benefit: Mobile through MVNO offers substantial revenue
and cost synergies without the need to spend say c.£9.1bn buying O2 (6.5x
EBITDA - a discount which we feel is justified given the blocked Hutch offer
at 7.3x and lack of alternatives for the seller). Sky can cross-sell mobile/
SIM cards to its own customer base at extremely low SAC. This should
help reduce churn. With c.11m UK-based DTH customers, and churn of
c.10.5%, Sky is having to replace at least 1.1m customers a year at a high
SAC. Sky can also use in-home femto cells within its broadband routers
to back-haul mobile signals through the customer's own line, further
reducing MVNO payments.

BE

Changes to estimates: We have raised revenue estimates by 5.2% in FY17
and 5.8% in FY18, partly driven by higher EUR translation from the German
and Italian businesses (c.30% group revenue). EBITDA is less affected as
the new units currently only contribute 14% of group EBITDA. We have
lowered FY17E EBITDA by 1.1% and FY18E by 0.3%.
Valuation: We derive our PT of 1,100p using DCF and a multiple-based

SOTP. Sky currently trades on projected 15.0x June 17 P/E, 9.4x EV/EBITDA,
and has an 8.0% FCF yield and 3.9% dividend yield.

11:41 am
BE

Meanwhile, over at BT, the Parliamentary report on Openreach is out, and it calls for lots of reforms.

BE

None of which will happen, of course, but whatever.

BE

Macquarie's read it for is.

11:42 am
BE

The CMS Committee asserts that BT has: (1) significantly under-invested in Openreach, with the shortfall estimated at "hundreds of millions of pounds a year"; (2) deliberately invested in media in preference to Openreach infrastructure; (3) exploited vertical integration to make strategic decisions which favour the group's priorities and interests; (4) allowed customer service levels at Openreach to remain low; and (5) impaired rival operators' network planning by obscuring transparency around Openreach deployment plans. The Committee demands that BT invest "significantly more" in Openreach allow Openreach management "much more" autonomy over its investments. It says that if BT fails to "offer the reforms and investment assurances necessary to satisfy our concerns", Ofcom should enforce full separation of Openreach.

PM

( WShak -- any sense of why they are doing that?)

BE

What does this mean? Nothing, really.

11:42 am
BE

Ofcom May Feel Empowered to Take a Harder Line. DCR proposals are expected before end-July. There continues to be uncertainty as to exactly how hard Ofcom will push for independent governance at Openreach, even after several months of negotiation. The final report will make Ofcom's position clear. Today's CMS Committee report may be significant insofar as Ofcom may feel more empowered to take a harder line with BT if it feels that influential politicians (and government) are supportive of radical change. BT has said that it can operate within a strengthened functional separation framework with more visibility on investment but that it would strongly resist any outcome it considers disproportionate. While the regulator will be aware that an appeals process through the EU could delay reform, the hiatus would arguably damage BT as well insofar as the process for getting regulatory visibility on next-stage fibre deployments (G.fast and FTTP) would probably also be delayed, to the detriment of BT's retail position.

BE

(@JL: premarket I think.)

BE

(@Flaneur: ?)

11:43 am
BE

BT Can Justifiably Feel Aggrieved. Little recognition from the CMS Committee that the speed of Openreach's FTTC deployment has made 30Mpbs+ broadband access available to greater than 80% of UK premises, that the investment was initially risky and that Openreach has met Ofcom service targets. Fact remains, however, that by allowing customer service to become a high-profile issue, BT has conceded the support it ought to have been able to count on as FTTC deployment nears completion and Ofcom looks forward to incentivising next-stage fibre deployments. In our 20 Apr report, Visibility Impaired; Downgrade to Hold, we suggested that intense pressure over recent years to drive cost savings down to the bottom line may have limited BT's headroom to tackle issues that compromise customer service.

Implications for Dividend-Paying Capacity. In a 21 June report, UK Consumer Survey: Attitudes and Perceptions in a Converging Market, we argued that compromise with Ofcom may involve BT committing to higher investment and a costly toughening up of service standards. Demands made today by the CMS Committee look consistent with that. BT's dividend pay-out has climbed from 45% of FCF post pension in FY12/13 to 64% by FY15/16. An incremental £400m p.a of capex could push this ratio up to c.90% over 4 years. And that is before taking into account the possibility of higher pension deficit funding following next June's triennial review .

BT Group (BT.A:LSE): Last: 391.90, down 3.1 (-0.79%), High: 395.15, Low: 388.80, Volume: 6.71m
undefined

This Zalando thing mentioned earlier on the right

PM

PM

11:44 am
PM

German online frocks

PM

Good luck with that

PM

I ahve one of those slightly irritating UBS Q&As on it

11:45 am
PM

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?
A: Q2 sales are between €909-924m (24-26% increase) v cons €916m or 25% growth. The surprise was on EBIT margin which is set to come in between 7.5-9.5% or €68-88m compared to consensus €46m or 5%. At the mid-point this is a €32m beat or c.70% ahead of consensus for Q2.

Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
A: The new mid point of FY EBIT margin guidance of 4-5.5% or 4.8% would give a c.20% EBIT uplift compared to current consensus.

Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?
A: FY16 guidance is for revenue growth at "upper end" of 20-25% corridor (consensus 25%) with adj EBIT margin of 4-5.5% from 3-4.5% previously (consensus 4.0%)

Q: How would we expect investors to react?
A: Concern has been growing on EBIT margin development and threat from Amazon and this upgraded guidance will provide a good relief rally we think.

BE

I like those slightly irritating UBS Q&As

PM

What UBS doesnt ask and doesnt answer is how Zalando is necessarily different or superior to the 1000 other online frock sites out there

11:46 am
PM

But -- whatever

undefined
BE

(@Flaneur: know nothing whatsoever about it, and we're not yet at a point where we're taking terminally unfunny parody accounts as primary sources.)

11:48 am
BE

............. So, what else? Coke HBC?

Coca Cola HBC AG (CCH:LSE): Last: 1,560, up 39 (+2.56%), High: 1,568, Low: 1,540, Volume: 345.82k
BE

So I wasn't here for the Arm bid, but I've made it back in time for the Cazenove upgrade of a Coca-Cola bottler.

11:49 am
BE

Phew.

BE

It's an industry explainer.

BE

The Coca-Cola bottling system is undergoing significant change with the
refranchise of NAm bottling, formation of CCEP ($18bn mkt cap) in Europe
last month and the commencement of CCBA (40% of Africa bottling)
operations in early July. The category has proved more resilient than beer or
spirits to macroeconomic volatility and the bottlers provide low beta
predictable cashflows through volume growth in a low inflation world. Benign
input costs and cost saving opportunities augment margin expansion. We
upgrade CCH to OW as it is best placed in this environment. We remain
cautious on BVIC and would buy more resilient BAG and RG.

11:49 am
BE

 CCH upgrade to Overweight. The soft drinks category is very resilient to
macroeconomic volatility which bodes well for CCH given current
uncertainty in Europe. We believe CCH’s medium-term guidance is
strongly underpinned by positive operating leverage on a now more
efficient cost base and we see room for significant further cost optimisation,
particularly in the key EMs of Russia and Nigeria. Given strong FCF
generation, we expect the balance sheet to be left under-geared within a
year, and we expect CCH will either return capital (€1bn is 18% of market
cap) or invest in value accretive M&A. The Coca-Cola bottling landscape is
currently changing in Africa and we believe CCH is well placed (track
record in Nigeria and ability to invest) to take on additional bottling assets
in key growth territories.

BE

 The soft drinks category is very resilient in the face of volatile
macroeconomic trends with volume growth even through economic
downturns. The mature W European soft drinks market grew volume by
1% each in 2008 and 2009 (versus beer and spirits down M-HSD). The
lack of pricing power matters far less in this low inflation world.
 Remain cautious on BVIC and buy BAG as our preferred way to gain
exposure to the UK soft drinks market. BVIC consensus has not reflected
the risk of a UK slowdown and the gross margin impact of weak GBP and
we expect CCEP to be a more competitive in the UK helped by cost
savings. BAG has more favourable category and channel exposure, strong
balance sheet and self help opportunities, in our view. We are OW on RG as
a play on European private label and co-packing M&A.

BE

 Valuation. CCH trades on a CY17E PE of 17.0x, BVIC on 13.3x, BAG
on 16.4x and RG on 11.3x vs. the European Beverages sector on 19.5x.

11:51 am
BE

We've written at least a dozen times about HBC buying Cola Beverages Africa.

BE

It looks sensible on paper, and it certainly looks sensible in the Cazenove note.

BE

Cazenove being an advisor to SAB on the Inbev bid, and SAB being a key stakeholder in Cola Beverages Africa.

11:52 am
undefined
BE

PM

Alongside operator Horse Hill Developments Limited, Solo has announced the results of a new petrophysical analysis undertaken by consultancy Nutech for the Horse Hill discovery. This follows strong flow test results (as previously reported) from the Horse Hill-1 well and sees a significant upgrade to previously calculated oil-in-place in the Upper Portland zone, which has risen three-fold to 22.9mmbbl per square mile. The flow test data analysis work has provided sufficient encouragement for the operator to begin preparations for a planning application and seek environmental approvals for an appraisal programme at Horse Hill, including long term testing of four zones, 3D seismic data acquisition and appraisal/development drilling (incorporating a planned horizontal sidetrack well). A public consultation process relating to the planning application will take place shortly, ahead of the anticipated submission of relevant applications early in the fourth quarter of this year. We remain highly encouraged by results from Horse Hill and look forward to commencement of the next stage of the work programme here; we continue to believe that Solo has a winning combination of non-operated interests spanning the E&P value chain, also noting (in Tanzania) the high levels of well deliverability being achieved at Kiliwani North and near term drilling plans for Ruvuma; we calculate Risked NAV of 1p/share.
